poem:
Missed Opportunities

A catalogue of failures
piled like autumn leaves,

each

one 
        a whisper:

                 what if?

Years crept,
the cells cold.

Seventeen years,
a man—innocence

buried,

waiting beneath
forgotten branches.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Catalogue of failures’: watchdog missed chances to help Andrew Malkinson, report finds A report on the Criminal Cases Review Commission’s handling of the Andrew Malkinson case has laid bare “a catalogue of failures”, finding that he could have been exonerated almost a decade earlier. The review by Chris Henley KC found that the watchdog missed multiple opportunities to help Malkinson, who spent 17 years in jail for a 2003 stranger rape he did not commit.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: ‘Catalogue of failures’: watchdog missed chances to help Andrew Malkinson, report finds A report on the Criminal Cases Review Commission’s handling of the Andrew Malkinson case has laid bare “a catalogue of failures”, finding that he could have been exonerated almost a decade earlier. The review by Chris Henley KC found that the watchdog missed multiple opportunities to help Malkinson, who spent 17 years in jail for a 2003 stranger rape he did not commit.
